titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VII.— Morning visits to Mr Gallatin, Mr Bayard, and Mr Russell— Mr Gallatin goes to-morrow Morning by the Diligence to Dieppe; to embark there for England— The Neptune is to wait at Brest for Mr Bayard, until the first of May— Mr Bayard expects to be able to leave this City for Brest in ten days from this time— He is to join the Neptune at Brest; and they are to touch in England to take Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay. I found Mr Bayard just ready to remove this morning to Mr Crawford’s house— He appeared to me very little, if any thing better than when I saw him last. He says that by reckoning the intervals from four to four days he finds he gains strength. But he is dissatisfied with his physician, the third he has already had, and has consulted a fourth, whom he likes better— He has for the last four or five days, rode out two or three hours every day— Mr Russell was just about dressing to go and be presented to Bernadotte’s wife— The Crown-Princess of Sweden— The weather was too warm for walking; so that after these visits, and one to Mr Todd I returned home, and received a visit from Mr Victor de Tracy— We went in the Evening to the Odeon and saw Il Matrimonio Secreto— One of the best performers, Porto, as he was entering upon the Stage, stumbled and fell, and was so severely hurt by the fall, that it was with extreme difficulty he went through his part. He was almost constantly upon the Scene, and the great pain he was evidently suffering ruined all the pleasure of the performance— The Music was still more delightful at this second hearing than it had been at the first. We met General Turreau at the Theatre— He complimented me upon the Ratification of the Ghent Treaty—and I complimented him, upon his being restored to active service— He smiled and said that he rejoyced at the late Revolution, first for the Emperor’s Account, and next for his own— For if the Bourbons had continued, he and many others would have lost
their heads— I said that I had no doubt but his situation would have been made uneasy; but I could scarcely believe that his life would have been endangered— He said I might depend upon it that there was a project against his life— That they had gone even so far as to reproach him for not having surrendered soon enough the fortress where he had commanded— I asked him if there was any news from the South, where it is reported that Bordeaux and Marseilles still hold out for the king— He said no—every thing was tranquil— But there was much false news circulated at Paris, as well as in America— You have not said he laughing, an exclusive privilege for that sort of manufacture. It is however certain that affairs are not yet settled in the South.

2. VII:15. Recovered once more the arrears of this Journal— We all went to see the Museum des Monumens Français, a Collection of the sepulchral Monuments taken from the Churches of the suppressed Monasteries— They are ranged in Chronological order from the fourth to the eighteenth Century inclusive— There are separate halls for the 13th: 14th: 15th. 16th: 17th: and 18th: centuries. A part of the most recent monuments are in the garden, which we did not see; the workmen being employed there upon repairs. The monuments are all numbered, and there is a volume sold at the entrance, containing the description of them all— They form altogether a History of the Art of Sculpture in France— Many of them were mutilated, during the frenzy of the Revolution in 1793. and have been restored by the care of Mr Le Noir, the keeper of this Cabinet— One of the singular mutilations is that of the inscription upon the Monument of Lebrun the celebrated Painter under Louis 14, every word of reference to royalty, in this inscription was struck out of the marble by a chissel and the rest of the Inscription was left entire— But the figures themselves of some of the finest monuments were broken; particularly those of Louis 11. and Cardinal Richelieu— After passing two hours there we walked round the Garden of the Tuileries, and through the Palais Royal— Evening at the Theatre Feydeau, or Opera Comique— La jeune femme Colere, L’homme sans facon, and le Tableau Parlant— The two first of which are miserable pieces, and the third, with the exquisite harmony of Gretry was wretchedly performed— Worse I think than I ever saw it at any theatre.

3. VII:15. Had an almost sleepless Night owing to the warmth of the weather, and was confined to the house all this Morning by the rain. The peach trees are in full blossom, and the trees in the gardens are nearly covered with leaves— About an hour before dinner I walked out with Charles, but was obliged soon after to return. Found and purchased a set of the Bibliotheca Graeca of Fabricius— Received a Letter of 4 March from Mr Harris, and the Letter which I wrote to my wife 5 Feby. from this place was returned this Evening. The Post from Germany has been detained only a few days at the frontier— In the Evening we went, without Charles to the Theatre de l’Ambigu Comique— Saw le Voyage au tour de ma chambre, le Bon Valet, and le Fils Banni a Melodrame, one of the best I have seen— I had never been at this theatre before— The house was full; but the Company almost universally unfashionable.

4. VII:15. There was rain again all the morning— I walked out with Charles between two and three O’Clock, but was obliged soon to return— We went to the National Museum but found it shut. Dined with Mrs Adams, at Mr and Mrs Hottinguer’s, en famille— Mr Crawford, Mr Iseling, a Mr Rogers, of New-York, with Mr and Miss Bayard, of the same place were of the company— In the Evening we played whist— Mr Crawford, Mr Iseling, Mr Rogers and myself— Afterwards, Mr Hottinguer took the place of Mr Rogers— It was Midnight when we came home.— I have been occupied all the leisure, time of this and the two preceding days, in the arrangement of my accounts.

5. VII:30. I received this morning a Letter from Mr Beasley, London dated 31 March, with the account of news from America, and the information that Mr Gallatin is appointed Minister to France, Mr Bayard to Russia, and Myself to England. Mr Monroe Secretary of State—and Captains Rodgers, Hull and Porter, Commissioners of a Navy-Board. I called upon Mr Crawford to enquire if he had received the English Newspapers, but he had not. Mr Crawford told me that he had seen the Duke de Vicence, and finding that there was nothing to be done upon the subject of indemnities, he had determined to return to America immediately— He said the Duke de Vicence told him that before the other foreign Ministers went away he had seen almost all of them, and he had sent to them all a declaration to take away all pretence of a doubt with regard to the pacific intentions of the emperor— He said also that the Correspondence and Records in the department of foreign affairs since the return of the Bourbons showed that there had been a long deliberation and hesitation in the Royal Council, whether France should not declare War against the United States, and make common Cause with Great-Britain— And when it was finally determined to declare a neutrality, the Instructions to the commanding Officers in all the Ports were to comply with every thing to gratify the English— While I was with Mr Crawford, General Turreau came in— He was in full Uniform, and complained again of being totally ruined; but said he was better since the late Events, and should perhaps be again employed by the Emperor— He said he had published a Book, or rather a pamphlet concerning the United States— That he censured, not the American Nation, but their Institutions; and as he expected soon to publish a second Edition, referring to the Events since he left America, and particularly to those of the late War with England, he should speak with eulogium upon the conduct of the Americans in the War, and particularly by sea— He wished to ask Mr Crawford, for any authentic information he could furnish him with on the subject, especially of the last campaign, and the affair at
New-Orleans— Mr Crawford promised him General Jackson’s Reports— I left them and called upon Mr Bayard, whom I found much better than when I saw him last Saturday— He considers himself and his physicians and Surgeons now consider him out of all danger; but he said he had had a very narrow escape with his life— I showed him Beasley’s Letter— He said he did not suppose the Government would consider him under an obligation to accept his appointment, and most assuredly he should not go to St Petersburg. His health would not admit of it— He should if possible undertake the Journey to Brest in ten or fifteen days; and return to the United States in the Neptune. On returning from Mr Crawford’s, I went with Mrs Adams and Charles to the annual public Meeting of the second Class of the Institute, or French Academy— Mr de Tracy had furnished us with two tickets— The meeting was opened at three O’Clock, and was presided by the Abbé Sicard— A Report was read by Count Francois de Neufchateau concerning the prizes which the academy had granted—to two poems on the last moments of the Chevalier Bayardi one was by Alexandre Soumet, and the other by Madame Dufresnoy—to a poem on the discovery of vaccination; by the same Alexandre Soumet—and to a Memoir upon the question why the Rhythm of the Greek and Latin Languages could not be applied to the French. Mr Soumet and the Abbé Scoppa received the accolade fraternelle from the President— Madame Dufresnoy was not present, but so that the same compliment was not paid to her— Extracts were also read from two or three of the poems on the subjects proposed by the Class, which had failed of obtaining the prize— It was observed that the first prize ever bestowed by the Academy was obtained by a woman— It was Mademoiselle de Scuderi—in 1671. and that since that time no other instance of the same kind had occurred until the present— The best poem was that Soumet upon vaccination— The Meeting was closed about four O’Clock— We then went and walked in the garden of the Tuileries; there was a great crowd assembled under the Emperor’s windows, and he came and threw open one of the windows, and shewed himself to them— We had a full view of him— Evening at the Theatre de la Gaieté— Le Chien de Montargis, and La fille mal gardée, a ballet.— Les Maitresses filles had been performed before we got there.

6. VII:30. We went to the Conservatoire des Arts et Métiers, and saw the collection of models of all the patent-machines, which have been deposited there— They are in the former Convent of St Martin. The Collection is large, and well arranged; but the patents are not so numerous as I should have expected— Among them is a ploughshare invented by Mr Jefferson— There was a balance upon which I steppd and found my weight to be 170 lb avoirdupois— Charles weighed only 50 lb.— Walked with him on the Boulevards and to the Coachmakers where the Carriage is left— I gave him the directions for the necessary repairs— Mr Erving called upon us after dinner— Evening at the Odeon— Amelie and Le Collatéral— The first piece was nearly half-finished when we arrived. Visits from Mr May, & Mr Dorr.

7. VII:30. Morning visits from Mr Petry, and Mr Ely, and while I was gone out from Mr Russell and Mr Todd— Mr Russell goes the day after to-morrow, upon his return to Sweden, and left word that if I wished to see him before he goes I must call this Evening or to-morrow morning not later than eleven O’Clock to-morrow Morning.— On returning home from my walk I found a packet from Mr Beasley, with a letter from him of the first instant, and enclosing letters from my father, mother and brother to the 10th: of March— They came in a vessel from Boston to Liverpool, and were brought by Mr Wurts of Philadelphia from London.— In the Evening we went to the Opera Comique, Rue Feydeau— Saw Blaise et Babet, le Calife de Bagdad, and les deux petits Savoyards—the House almost empty; and the performances all very indifferent.

8. VII:15. At eleven this morning I called upon Mr Russell, and found Mr Joseph Russell with him— I also paid a visit to Mr Todd, with whom I found Coll: Milligan— Heard some further Accounts from America— Asbury Dickins is appointed Consul at London— Mr Beasley, Consul at Gibraltar— A. H. Everett, Secretary to Dr Eustis the Minister to Holland— The Transit, with Mr Hughes, Boyd and Shaler, arrived at New-London the 3d: of March, after a passage of 53 days from the river of Bordeaux— Mr Russell called upon me at one O’Clock—we went to the Rue des Postes and took up his Son George and young Mason, Son of General Mason of Georgetown. We went to the Catacombs a subterraneous sepulchre, where the bones of two millions of the inhabitants of Paris are deposited. The descent is by a winding stair-case of 77 steps to a depth of 55 french feet under ground—each person takes with him a lighted taper. The caverns are spacious, distributed in alleys about eight feet wide, and seven feet high on each side of which the bones are ranged like a tapestry to the walls, a black streak on the cieling directs the course to and from the stair-case at the entrance— And at small intervals there are placed stones with pious and moral inscriptions— From this place we went and visited the manufacture of the Gobelin Tapestry, where we found fifty or sixty workmen employed upon the atchievements of the Emperor Napoleon.— I then took leave of Mr Russell, went home with young Mason, and returned to our Hotel to dinner— Mr de Tracy and Madame Hottinguer had paid visits to Mrs Adams— In the Evening we went to the Theatre du Vaudeville— Saw le Mariage de Scarron; l’Exil de Rochester, and La
Vallée de Barcelonnette— While at the Theatre I was seized with a severe hoarseness which much affected my voice. On returning home I was quite unwell— I have been troubled several days with a Cold; but thought it was passed.

9. VII:15. My hoarseness was troublesome in the Night and continued so the whole of this day.— The oppression upon my breast is considerable, but as yet without a cough— My voice is much affected— I do not however confine myself— I paid visits to Mr Crawford, Mr Bayard, and Mr Erving; but found neither of them at home— Then went to the Place du Carousel where the Emperor was reviewing troops.— It was impossible from the concourse of people to approach near enough to the Court of the Tuileries to see any thing of the review. Afterwards I walked in the Garden of the Tuileries, which was throughout, crowded with people— Under the Emperor’s windows the throng was very great. He came and stood about five Minutes at one of the windows and was hailed with loud and general acclamations of Vive l’Empereur.— I had a more distinct view of his face than when I had last seen him— On my return home, I purchased in one of the shops at the Palais Royal a volume just published, entitled one year of the life of the Emperor Napoleon, with which I amused myself until dinner time— Evening at the Théatre Francais— Le Tartuffe, and Les fausses Confidences—both performed in the highest Style of excellence.— Fleury, Devigny, Armand, Thénard, the younger Baptiste, Madame Thenard, Mlle Demerson, and above all Mlle. Mars made it one of the most perfect theatrical representations I ever witnessed— The house was overflowing; and there was some boisterous clamours for the Airs La Victoire—Le chant du Depart—and La Lyonnaise.

10. VII:15. I had an uneasy Night, and continued the whole of this day unwell with a severe catarrh— I betake myself to nostrums. Mr Crawford paid me a morning visit— He goes to-morrow to visit General La Fayette; at his Country Seat of La Grange. He said that if the Neptune should come round to Havre, he should embark in her, to return to the United States— He expects she will sail about the first of May— He is appointed Secretary at War, and will accept the appointment— We had also morning visits from Mr Hubbard, Mr: Joseph Russell, Mr Hottinguer, and Mr Robert Boyd— Mr Hubbard told us he had just been to the Mayor’s Office to register the birth of his daughter’s twins just born— Mr Russell went on board the Fingal with Mr and Mrs Smith when they embarked— They sailed with a fair wind from Havre, on the 30th: of March— Our visitors occupied almost the whole Morning— I walked out an hour before dinner, and after dinner we all walked in the garden of the Luxemburg palace, after which we went to the Odeon Theatre and saw Il fanatico in Berlina— On returning home I was very unwell.

11. VII:15. The oppression at my breast is greater than I remember ever to have suffered before; I had an almost sleepless and excessively restless night, with considerable fever— I thought myself however much better all the first part of this day— Had a morning visit from Mr Francis Williams— Mr Boyd came and accompanied Mrs Adams to see her old friend Madame de Cadignan, and after wards Mrs Hottinguer. I walked with Charles on the Boulevard, in the Garden of the Tuileries, and through the arches of the Palais Royal— Purchased the Dictionnaire de l’Académie Françoise, and the last Edition of the Dictionnaire Historique by Chaudon and Delandine, in twenty volumes. After dinner we took a ride out to Auteuil, and returned by the way of Passy and Chaillot. It was eight O’Clock, and dark when we got home— From dinner time I found my complaint coming again upon me severely, and in the Evening was so unwell that I found it painful to speak— Took a foot-bath before going to bed— Mr Jackson, the Secretary to Mr Crawford’s Legation, sent me the late New-York Newspapers, to 11. March, received from Mr Beasley— They contain very little news.

12. VIII. Another restless and almost sleepless Night— The impatience of my temper aggravates all my complaints.— I find myself so much better every morning that I fancy myself quite recovered— Every Evening brings a disappointment, and each night is worse than its last predecessor— This day until dinner time I suffered little— There was a thunder-shower, so that I was confined all the morning to the house— I employed it in writing, and bringing into order my accounts— After dinner we took a ride round the Boulevards to the Porte St: Antoine; and returned by the Place Royale, the Quays and the Place du Carousel— My eldest Son, George is this day fourteen years old. Charles measures 3 feet 10 1/2 inches.

13. VI. A worse Night than the two last— Waked between 3 and 4 O’Clock, and rose at six; finding it insupportable to keep my bed any longer. The oppression upon my breast continues, and this day has become very painful— I sent for a physician— Dr Hallé, who has attended Mr Bayard, and was strongly recommended by him and by Mrs Hottinguer— He sent for answer that he was confined himself to his chamber, but gave advice to patients who could call upon him there— I occupied myself all the morning as well as I could— Walked out before dinner, as far as the garden of the Tuileries— Caught for half an hour in a shower of rain, and sheltered myself in the passage way, between the garden, and the yard adjoining the place du Carrousel— Mrs Adams and Charles rode out this Evening; I kept my chamber, and read as long as my eyes would admit. My complaint as usual was more troublesome as the Night came on.

14. I had a more quiet Night and rested until near 5 O’Clock this Morning— After rising I was so much better than the preceding days, that I thought my complaint removed— On walking out I was suprized at the change of weather which has become cold and boisterous. I paid visits to Mr Erving and Mr Van Rensselaer— Neither of them was at his lodgings— At a Bookseller’s shop in the Palais-Royal, I met Mr: de Torcy, who informed me where Count Theodore Golowkin lives— Mrs Adams brought a packet for him from his Sister the Countess de Bruges, and we had not yet been able to find him— On returning home I found my throat sore, and in the Evening my cough was more troublesome and painful than it has yet been— I compared some of the quotations from Virgil, in a letter which I lately received from Mr Cornelissen; with the book which I purchased at the Palais-Royal for the purpose.

15. VI.30. Had a tolerably good Night’s rest— The Cold is passing off; but leaves the cough behind— Mr R. Boyd paid us a long visit. I walked an hour before dinner, and in the Evening we went to the Theatre des Varietés. Saw La famille des Innocens, Boileau à Auteuil, La Piece qui n’en est pas une, and Le Bucheron de Salerne.— I occupy myself as much as my indisposition allows with the arrangement of my accounts.

16. VII:15. The weather has become so cold and raw again that we have found it necessary to renew the making of fires in our chambers.— The Emperor Napoleon this day reviewed the National Guards of Paris in the Court Yard of the Tuileries— We went there between two and three O’Clock, when the review was just closing.— We walked in the Garden and on the Place du Carrousel— Returning home I called at Mr Erving’s lodgings, but he was not at home— Purchased Madame de Sevigne’s Letters and a small Stereotype Anacharsis— Evening at the French Theatre— Le Dissipateur and La Jeunesse de Henry 5— The latter I had seen at St Petersburg— The Dissipateur is one of the characteristic Plays of Destouches, and feeble in comic humour— Henry Thénard, Baptiste the younger, Armand, Mlle. Mars and Mlle Dupuis made as much of it as could be made, and that was very little.— We left Charles at home.

17. VII:30. Morning visit from Mr Irving, and Evening one from Mr R. Boyd— The great and sudden change of weather has increased my cold, and aggravated my cough— Walked out with Charles an hour before dinner, and we all rode out after dinner. I met Mr Crawford this morning walking upon the Boulevards— He returned on Friday from his visit to General La Fayette— He had a letter this morning from Mr Clay dated the 6th. instant— He speaks of embarking at Liverpool to return to America.

18. VI: My complaint after having been apparently in a great degree removed has returned with more violent symptoms— Had a morning visit from Mr Jos. Russell, and walked an hour before dinner with Charles— Although the state of my health makes it troublesome to write I began a Letter to the Secretary of State— In the Evening I took a foot bath— I read a few pages of the Description of Paris, and Carnot’s Memorial, presented to the king last July— It was a bold step of Carnot, to publish it at that time but the Events of this time are the best commentary upon it, and a justification of the Sentiments it contains.

19. VI. After an indifferent Night, I was this morning more unwell than I had been, hitherto— It was with difficulty that I continued writing to the Secretary of State, which I could not finish— I paid visits to Mr May and Mr Le Roy de Chaumont— The former of whom only was at home— I walked back to the Hotel, where I found Dr Roberton. Mrs Adams had sent for him to see me. He is the physician who has attended Mr Crawford and Mr Bayard— He prescribed for me, and recommended precisely the regimen that I have been following these ten days— Mrs Adams dined at Mr Hottinguer’s— I sent an excuse on account of my indisposition. Spent the Evening in my chamber hearing Charles read, and reading, myself.

20. V.45. I found myself better this morning— Mrs Adams had intended to pay visits this morning; but Warden, and Mr Boyd successively came in and detained us until it was too late— I walked to the Tuileries with Charles, and as we were returning I lost him in the Palais Royal— The Doctor had prescribed to me to be careful and avoid such exercise which would produce strong perspiration; but in the search for Charles I forgot the injunction— After seeking him in vain nearly half an hour I returned to the Hotel more to take Louis and Antoine to renew the search with me, than with the hope to find it unnecessary; but I found Charles had got home without me, having found his own way through the Streets— In the Evening we went to the Theatre des Varietés.— Mr Crédule; le Cordier de Samarcande—le Menage de Mr Crouton; and Les Anglaises pour rire.

21. V:30. I finished with difficulty my Letter to the Secretary of State, and began one to my Mother. Was confined all the morning to the house by the weather— Dr Roberton paid me a second visit; and I had also a visit from Mr Crawford— He thinks of going early in the course of next week for England; and intends to leave Mr Jackson here as Chargé d’Affaires. He had received this morning letters from Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay, of the 15th: instant. Neither of them had decided upon his movements. Dr Roberton
speaks doubtfully of the case of Mr Bayard; and thinks he has yet an internal abscess for which the breast-bone must be trepanned— Mr Bayard still intends however to go to Havre as soon as the Neptune arrives there; and to return in her to America. Mr Crawford told us that he heard the Emperor was going this Evening to the French Theatre— I went with Mrs Adams— The Emperor was there; but we could get seats only in a box on the same side of the Theatre as he was seated, and we could not see him— The house was so crowded that the Musicians of the Orchestra were driven from their Seats and the music was heard only from behind the scenes— The Airs of La Victoire, Veillons au Salut de l’Empire and la Marseillaise were called for and played repeatedly— A Gentleman in one of the Balconies was called upon to sing some couplets, now in circulation— He said that he did not know them; but if they were furnished him, he would sing them with pleasure— They were immediately passed to him, and he sung them amidst loud and continual shouts of Vive l’Empereur. The Parterre joining in the Chorus— The Couplets were indifferent. The performances were the Tragedy of Hector and Le Legs— Talma and Mademoiselle Duchesnois had just finished the first Scene, when the Emperor came in— He was received with redoubled and long continued shouts of Vive l’Empereur; after which there was a cry from the Parterre—recommencéz—accordingly they began the Play again— In all the intervals between the Acts, the shouts of Vive l’Empereur were renewed, and one or two persons in the Pit having put on their hats, as is usual between the Acts there was an immediate cry of Chapeaux bas! At the end of the Tragedy the Emperor went away— In the after-piece Mademoiselle Mars and Fleury were excellent; as Talma and Mlle. Duchesnois had been in the Tragedy.

22. VI:30. Morning visit from Mr Erving, who gave me some information of certain persons who he supposes will come to form an acquaintance with me in England; he mentioned the suppression by the Police, yesterday of a Volume of the Censeur, just published; I read him an Article of the Journal de l’Empire of this Morning, stating that the Censeur will be freely circulated and not suppressed.— He thought he had contributed to produce this reconsideration of the Police— Mr Barnet and Mr Appleton also called upon me; and invited me to attend a dinner next Monday, to be given by the Americans at Paris to Mr Crawford— I walked out before dinner with Charles, who found the way to the Tuileries; thence to the Palais-Royal, and back to our Hotel through the Rue Vivienne— I stopped at Le Roy’s a watchmaker; and took my watch that I had left with him to be cleaned— As we rose from dinner, Mr Todd came in, and gave us two tickets of admission for the Mass at the Tuileries to-morrow Morning— We rode out this Evening; my cough and sore throat have again become troublesome.

23. VII. At ten this morning, Mr Todd called upon us and we went to the Mass at the Chapel of the Tuileries— The tickets were marked for half past ten, but we were obliged to walk in the Garden near half an hour before we were admitted, and then waited an hour and a half longer before the Emperor came in— The Mass then began, and lasted less than half an hour— The music was excellent— The Opera-Singers Laÿs, Nourrit and Madame Albert assisted in the performance of the Service— The lower part of the chapel, where we were, was full of company— The Ladies only were seated, on benches— I had a full and steady view of the Emperor’s countenance. We met there an American whom I had not seen before, a Mr Carter, of Virginia— After the mass the Emperor reviewed his guards— We did not see him. We went to the Count de Tracy’s to pay visits to his Lady, and Madame de L’Aubépin his daughter— Madame de Tracy was not at home. We saw Madame de l’Aubépin, her husband and the Count de Tracy.— He told me his son was gone with a General upon a mission to the frontiers; but would return in the course of a week— I called also at Mr Crawford’s house, and saw him— He was packing up for his departure, and said he should leave Paris next Wednesday— Mr Bayard was riding out— On returning home I found General La Fayette had called to see me— A Mr Copeland also, of Boston, came and left Letters for me from Mr De Grand, with a file of Newspapers— I was engaged all the Evening in reading them.

24. VI:30. At home all the Morning, writing to my father— At five in the afternoon I went to the Restaurateur Grignon’s, in the Rue Neuve des Petits Champs; where the dinner was given by the Americans at Paris to Mr: Crawford— We sat down at Table, about six O’Clock, forty-five in number— Mr Barnet the Consul presided, and under him Mr Appleton, the Consul at Leghorn— The guests invited were, besides Mr Crawford, General La Fayette and his Son, Mr Erving, Coll: Milligan, Mr Todd, Mr Russell’s son George and myself— Two thirds of the company at least were unknown to me— The dinner was good; and we sat drinking Toasts, until between ten and eleven at Night. I came away leaving Mr Crawford and most of the company there— Mr Erving had left the table immediately after dinner, and before the toasts began.— General La Fayette told me that he had come to Paris at the request of Joseph Bonaparte; who had consulted him on the subject of the proposed supplementary Constitution, which was yesterday published in the Moniteur— He says it is very unpopular here; and he thinks the hereditary peerage particularly objectionable— He is also of opinion that they should have begun anew, without any reference to the former Constitutions; and that previously to presenting the present project to the acceptance of the People it should have been submitted to the discussion of an assembly of at least two members from each department of the Country. He
renewed the invitation to me to come with my family and spend some days with him at his Country Seat, La grange— I promised him to go out next Tuesday. Our young calculator Zerah Colburn, was at this dinner with his father— He spoke a short address to Mr Crawford, and gave his toast with the assurance of a man full grown; but without offensive boldness— He endeavoured to prevail upon George Russell to do the same, but George though a lively and intelligent boy had not so much confidence in himself— Mr Crawford was toasted in his presence, and the negotiators at Ghent in mine, according to an English custom, which I am sorry to see adopted by Americans. We did not however on our part adopt the custom by answering the toast with a speech.

25. VI:30. Made up my packages for the Secretary of State and my father, and wrote to Mr Beasley— I called at Mr Hottinguer’s and made arrangements for a draft upon Amsterdam— Thence went to Mr Crawford’s to take leave of him; but he was not at home. Mr Bayard had also rode out. I left the Letters that I had prepared to go by Mr Crawford, with Mr Jackson, his Secretary of Legation, whom he leaves here as Chargé des Affairs, and took home with me the Volumes of Niles’s Register, which Mr Connell had sent for me— I took also from Mr Jackson a Cerificate for the United States Stocks, brought by Mr Boyd, and which I had left with Mr. Crawford, on my first arrival at Paris— We intended to have gone to the Cirque Olympique of Franconi, but they had no performance this Evening, and we went to the Spectacle Instructif and Phantasmagorie of Robertson on the Boulevards— It is a combination of experiments in natural philosophy, optical illusions, acoustic phenomena, and slight of hand— Many of them were new to me. The Shadows are not so terrific as might be expected— He has one machine in the figure of a man who blows the trumpet; and one in the form of a child who by mere mechanical operation utters articulate sounds—distinct words— The least amusing part of his exhibition is the phantesmagorie— The slight of hand is by a Mr Barsi; superior to any thing I ever saw of the kind.— They kept us from half past seven, until eleven O’Clock— My cough still adheres to me.

26. VIII:30. A very late hour; and the consequence was that the day was in a great measure lost— Mr Todd paid us a morning visit. He had just come from Mr Crawford’s house, and informed us that he was gone— He left the City at eleven this Morning— I took a walk with Charles before dinner— In the Evening we all walked upon the Boulevards, and afterwards rode round the Bridge of Austerlitz, returning by the Quays; the Place de Louis Quinze and the Boulevards again— Read a few pages in the Description of Paris, and made a short Evening to rise earlier to-morrow Morning than this day.

27. V:30. Employed the morning in writing to Mr De Grand; we had a visit from Mr Petry, who appears to be again employed in the Department of foreign affairs— Walking out before dinner I met Mr Erving— After dinner I rode out with Mrs Adams to the Canal de l’Ourcq, and we walked about half a mile along the borders of the Canal. We returned home between eight and nine in the Evening— I attempted to read in the Description of Paris, but was compelled by my cough to desist.

28. VI. Though I rose thus early, I could write only part of a Letter to my brother— I am slow in the transaction of business. Mr Erving called upon me this morning— I am endeavouring to arrange with him an affair for some wines, belonging to Mrs Fenwick— Walked an hour before dinner, and in the Evening went with Mrs Adams and Charles to the Odeon Theatre, where we saw Les Querelles des deux Freres; le Mari battu et content, and Les précieuses Ridicules, all indifferently performed— The first is a posthumous piece of Collin d’Harleville’s, and much inferior to the optimiste and Vieux Celibataire.— Les Précieuses is one of the most truly comic of Moliére’s farces, but for the first time in my life I found it dull.— I was this day much relieved from my Cough— Mr Erving told me that Mr: Crawford immediately before his departure for England, had at the request of the Emperor’s brother Joseph, an interview with him— He says likewise that the Emperor yesterday said at his Audience, that Austria would not join in the War against France.

29. V:15. I could effect nothing more than finishing my Letter to my brother.— Having tried two of the samples of Mrs Fenwick’s wines, I concluded to take some of them, and called at her lodgings to speak for them— I found Mr Erving with her. Gave her the direction to be put upon the boxes, addressing them to myself at London. She promised to have them sent to the house where they are to be loaded for the Havre— I direct them there to the care of Messrs: Russell and La Farge.— I paid a visit before dinner to Mr Copeland, with whom I found Mr Ely, and a Mr Carnes of Boston, who told me he should go this Evening for London, and offered to take Letters for me— On returning home I found a Note from Mr Kittera to the same effect. He is going to-morrow: but he did not inform me of the house where he lodges— After dinner I went to the Hotel of the American Legation to see Mr Bayard; but his Servant told me he was already gone to bed. I then called at the Hotel de l’Empire, Rue Ceruti, again (it was lately Rue d’Artois) and saw Mr Todd and Coll: Milligan— I promised General La Fayette that I would come next Tuesday, and pay him a visit at his Seat at La Grange; and Mr Todd having lately been there in company with Mr Crawford, I made some
enquiries of him concerning the road— I finally ascertained precisely where it is— Madame Perrée, the wife of the man of whom I hire my Carriage and horses came here this morning to settle terms upon which they are to furnish horses for this tour; but she did not exactly know the place— Mr Todd has determined to embark in the Neptune at the Havre; and accordingly not to go first to England— Mr Bayard intends to leave Paris next Friday or Saturday, and the orders for the Neptune are to be ready to sail from Havre on the tenth of May.

30. VI. Wrote a Letter to the Secretary of State; but not the Letter I had intended— That is still to be written; and Mr Bayard goes so soon, that my visit to General la Fayette will come at an inconvenient time— Mrs Adams too is so averse to going with me, that I shall be obliged to go without her— I called again this morning upon Mrs Fenwick, and found the boxes of wines in her yard, all directed, and ready to be sent to the Bureau de Roulage to-morrow Morning. She asked me if her Son could not have permission to go as a passenger in the Neptune— I told her that Mr Bayard was the only person here to whom application must be made for this privilege, the other Gentlemen being in England— She requested me to speak to Mr Bayard in behalf of her Son— I promised her that I would, and give her the answer to-morrow-morning— I went immediately after dinner; between 6 and 7 O’Clock in the Evening, and found Mr Bayard, just before his bed-time. He complained that from 2 or 3 O’Clock afternoon until he went to bed he found himself feeble and exhausted, and dragging heavily on— In the Morning he was always better— I stated to him the request of Mrs Fenwick for her Son; but he said he could not authorize any person to go as passenger— He should not object to his going in the vessel to England, and to take his chance of obtaining the consent of the other Gentlemen there— In conversing upon this subject he was taken with a fit of coughing—observed that talking killed him, and asked me to call on him again to-morrow Morning. I left him with a promise that I would— Took an Evening ride with my wife and Charles, round by the Boulevards and Quays. G. Russell & Messrs: Dorr & May visited us.

Day— Differing little from that of the last Month, excepting that the last half of the month we have been to the theatres not more than two or three times a week. The Cold and cough with which I have been these three weeks afflicted, has prevented us from visiting the curiosities of the City— In the course of the last ten days I have been much occupied in writing Letters for America.
